isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - ROCKWELL TANDEM AXLE FORWARD REAR DRIVE UNITS - ASSEMBLE - ADJUSTING THE BEARING PRELOAD ON THE DRIVE PINION

svcproc.title: ADJUSTING THE BEARING PRELOAD ON THE DRIVE PINION

item.para: New Pinion Bearings: 5 - 45 in-lbs. (0.56 - 5.08 Nm). Torque to rotate.
Used Pinion Bearings: 10 - 30 in-lbs. (1.13 - 3.39 Nm). Torque to rotate.

note.para: If the depth of the drive pinion was changed, then the amount of change must be added or subtracted from the thickness of the spacer between the outer bearing cup and the helical driven gear.

svcproc.para: After you get the correct thickness for the shim pack, you must adjust the bearing preload on the drive pinion. The preload is controlled by the thickness of the spacer between the helical driven gear and the outer bearing cone ( Figure 80).

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. SPACER - ONLY AVAILABLE IN ONE SIZE
2. SPACER - AVAILABLE IN DIFFERENT SIZES TO ADJUST PRELOAD

warning.para: Observe all warnings and cautions concerning press operation to avoid serious personal injury and possible damage to components.

step1.para: Put the carrier in a press so that the threaded end of the pinion is facing up. Put supports under the flange of the carrier so that the carrier is level. Put a wood block under the head of the pinion ( Figure 81).

figure.caption: Figure 81. Remove Cone and Pinion Assembly

step1.para: Press the drive pinion out of the outer bearing cone. Remove the cone and pinion assembly ( Figure 81).
Turn the carrier over so that the legs of the carrier are facing up. Put supports under the carrier so that the carrier is level.

Put the helical driven gear over the pinion bore in the carrier so that the splines inside the gear are toward the front of the carrier. Put the large spacer on top of the helical driven gear so that the spacer is toward the inner bearing cup ( Figure 82).
Install the drive pinion through the spacer and into the helical driven gear. Make sure the splines on the pinion engage the splines inside the helical driven gear ( Figure 82).

caution.para: Do not apply pressure after the inner bearing cone touches the inner bearing cup. If pressure is applied, the cup, cone and drive pinion will be damaged.

step1.para: Put a protector on the head of the drive pinion. Use a press to install the pinion into the carrier so that the inner bearing cone touches the bearing cup. At this time, the helical driven gear will not be completely installed on the drive pinion ( Figure 82).

Put the carrier in a press so that the threaded end of the pinion is toward the top of the press. Put supports under the flange of the carrier so that the carrier is level. Put a wood block under the head of the drive pinion so the inner pinion bearing cone touches the inner bearing cup ( Figure 83).

caution.para: Do not apply pressure after the helical driven gear touches the spacer in front of the inner bearing on the drive pinion. If pressure is applied after the parts touch each other, the gear will damage the spacer.

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. WOOD BLOCK AND END OF DRIVE PINION MUST TOUCH

step1.para: Use a press and a sleeve to completely install the helical driven gear on the drive pinion. Press the gear on the drive pinion until the gear touches the spacer ( Figure 83).

Cut two pieces of lead or solder approximately .5625 inch (14 mm) long and .625 inch (16 mm) wide. Use the two pieces of solder or lead as gauge blocks to determine correct thickness of the spacer between the helical driven gear and the outer bearing.
Put the two pieces of lead or solder so that the pieces are opposite each other on top of the helical driven gear.
Put the outer bearing cone in the cup over the two pieces of lead or solder on top of the helical driven gear.

Remove the support from the flange of the carrier. Put a sleeve on top of the outer bearing cone. Use a press to apply only 2 tons (1814 kg) of force to the outer bearing cone. The force of the press compresses the lead or solder pieces to the correct size. DO NOT APPLY MORE THAN 2 TONS OF FORCE ( Figure 84).

figure.caption: Figure 84. Apply ONLY 2 Tons of Force

calloutgroup.callout1: 3. PRESS - DO NOT APPLY MORE THAN TWO TONS OF PRESSURE
6. WOOD BLOCK - MUST SUPPORT HEAD OF PINION

step1.para: Release the pressure and remove the wood block from under the head of the drive pinion.
Use a press and a sleeve to press the shaft of the drive pinion out of the outer bearing cone. DO NOT PRESS THE SHAFT OF THE DRIVE PINION OUT OF THE HELICAL DRIVEN GEAR.
Remove the outer bearing cone and the two pieces of lead or solder from the outer bearing cone.

Use a micrometer to measure the thicknesses of the compressed pieces of lead or solder. Add the measurements of the two pieces and divide by two (2) to determine the average size of the pieces. Add 0.004 inch (0.100 mm) to the average size. Use this dimension to determine the size of the spacer to install between the helical driven gear and the outer bearing.

entry.para: Thickness of Piece No. 1 Plus Thickness of Piece No. 2 Equals Total Thickness
Divide by Two (2) to Get Average Thickness
Add 0.004 Inch (0.100 mm) to Get Thickness of Spacer

step1.para: Put a wood block under the head of the drive pinion so that the inner bearing cone on the pinion touches the inner bearing cup in the carrier. Remove the supports from the carrier ( Figure 85).

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. ROTATE CARRIER IN THESE DIRECTIONS AS CONE IS PRESSED ON PINION
6. PRESS - DO NOT APPLY MORE THAN TWO TONS OF PRESSURE
8. WOOD BLOCK - MUST TOUCH HEAD OF DRIVE PINION

caution.para: Do not apply pressure after the helical driven gear touches the spacer in front of the inner bearing on the drive pinion. If the pressure is applied after the parts touch each other, the gear will damage the spacer.

note.para: The inner bearing cone on the drive pinion must touch the inner bearing cup in the carrier when the helical driven gear is being installed.

step1.para: Use a press and a sleeve to completely install the helical driven gear on the drive pinion. Press the gear on the drive pinion until the gear touches the spacer. Do not remove the wood block at this time ( Figure 84).
Install the correct size of spacer on the shaft of the pinion in front of the helical driven gear.

note.para: Make sure the wood block is still under the head of the drive pinion. The inner bearing cone on the pinion must touch the cup in the carrier.

step1.para: Install the outer bearing cone with a press and sleeve. Apply 2 tons (1814 kg) of force ( Figure 85). Rotate the carrier in both directions, pivoting on the pinion while pressing the bearing cone to insure that the bearing cone is correctly installed.

Install the washer and the nut on the drive pinion. Prevent the drive pinion assembly from rotating by using a suitable fixture to hold the teeth of the helical driven gear or put wood blocks between the head of the pinion and the carrier wall. Tighten the nut to the specified torque. Refer to the Torque Chart.

Use an inch-pound torque wrench to check the preload of the bearings on the drive pinion. Rotate the drive pinion assembly with an inch-pound torque wrench. Check and record the torque level. Read while rotating the assembly. Record the dynamic or torque to rotate ( Figure 86) - not the breakaway torque.
If preload is not within the specified limits, remove and replace the spacer between the outer bearing cone and the helical driven gear ( Figure 87).

item.para: Install a thicker spacer to decrease the preload.
Install a thinner spacer to increase the preload.

note.para: Do not grind spacers by hand. Surfaces must be parallel within 0.0001 inch (.002 mm). Be certain to use proper spacers.

calloutgroup.callout1: 6. WOOD BLOCK DOES NOT TOUCH DRIVE PINION

step1.para: Prevent the drive pinion assembly from rotating by using a fixture to hold the teeth of the helical driven gear or put wood blocks between the head of the pinion and the carrier wall. Remove the nut and the washer from the shaft of the drive pinion.
